channel.title: From The Archives - Digg
channel.description: From The Archives on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Oil Prices Just Crashed To Less Than $1/Barrel. Here's What It's Like To Actually Try To Buy A Barrel
item.description: Oil prices crashed to new lows on Monday amid the pandemic. Here's what happened when Bloomberg's Tracy Alloway tried to buy a barrel back in 2015.

item.title: How The Fiery Crash Of A Ferrari Enzo Exposed A Billion-Dollar Scam (2016)
item.description: It was an unprecedented multinational scam that burned investors from London to Los Angeles. How did a Swedish gangster end up overseeing a billion-dollar tech firm? And where did all the money go?

item.title: The Mystery Of The Millionaire Hermit (2019)
item.description: He spent years scrimping and saving. But without a will, where's his money going?

item.title: The World Is Not Ready For The Next Pandemic (2017)
item.description: On a hyperconnected planet rife with hyperinfectious diseases, experts warn we aren't ready to keep America — and the world — safe from the next pandemic

item.title: The Deadliest Virus Ever Known
item.description: The Spanish-flu epidemic of 1918 reached virtually every country, killing so many people so quickly that some cities were forced to convert streetcars into hearses.

item.title: Joe Exotic And His American Animals (2019)
item.description: Joe Exotic bred lions, tigers, and ligers at his roadside zoo. He was a modern Barnum who found an equally extraordinary nemesis.

item.title: Jordan Vogt-Roberts And The Attack On Skull Island (2018)
item.description: After the blockbuster success of "Kong: Skull Island," director Jordan Vogt-Roberts fled Hollywood to live the expat dream life in Vietnam. Then, one night at a Saigon club, he was brutally beaten by a mysterious mob of gangsters. Who were these monsters? Soon, he began directing something entirely different — an international hunt for the men who nearly killed him.

item.title: This Is What Happens When Bitcoin Miners Take Over Your Town (2018)
item.description: Eastern Washington had cheap power and tons of space. Then the suitcases of cash started arriving.

item.title: The Lottery Hackers
item.description: Jerry Selbee has always had an eye for puzzles and spotting patterns — which is how he discovered a lottery loophole that would eventually make him and his wife millionaires.

item.title: From Nazi Germany To Australia: The Incredible True Story Of History's Longest Kayak Journey (2018)
item.description: This is the story of Oscar Speck's voyage, a seven-and-a-half-year adventure nearly lost to history.

item.title: Losing Conner's Mind (2018)
item.description: The race to save a child from a genetic death sentence.
item.kicker: 'BLUE WAS THE FIRST WORD CONNER LOST'

item.title: The Most Hated Poet In Portland (2017)
item.description: One tweet turned Collin Andrew Yost into a joke. Could he survive it?

item.title: How Renting Furniture In Texas Can Land You In Jail (2017)
item.description: While other businesses have to use civil remedies when customers don't pay their debts, the rent-to-own industry has a special tool in Texas law that lets them file criminal charges.

item.title: The Most Hated Woman On The Russian Internet (2017)
item.description: Anna Zhavnerovich knew she was taking a risk when she publicized the details of her assault online. But in doing so, she joined a growing movement of survivors fighting back against Russia's Kremlin-influenced trolling machine.

item.title: Inside the Mind of Thru-Hiking's Most Devious Con Man
item.description: For more than two decades, Jeff Caldwell has lured in hikers, couchsurfers, and other women (and they're almost always women), enthralling them with his tales of adventure. Then he manufactures personal crises and exploits their sympathy to rip them off.

item.title: The Sordid Double Life Of Washington's Most Powerful Ambassador (2017)
item.description: Yousef al-Otaiba, the UAE's influential ambassador to Washington, led a hard-partying life that eventually collided with his professional world.
item.kicker: A MEMBER OF THE PARTY PARTY

item.title: Parents Who Pay To Be Watched (2017)
item.description: Armed with Nest Cams and 24/7 surveillance, one company promises to fix even the most dysfunctional child — for a price.

item.title: How Online Shopping Makes Suckers Of Us All (2017)
item.description: Will you pay more for those shoes before 7 pm? Would the price tag be different if you lived in the suburbs? Standard prices and simple discounts are giving way to far more exotic strategies, designed to extract every last dollar from the consumer.

item.title: The Man Who Broke Ticketmaster (2017)
item.description: The most infamous ticket scalper of all time used bots to buy millions of tickets. Now he wants to stop them.

item.title: The Darkest Town In America (2017)
item.description: Over 100 miles from Reno, 240 miles from Sacramento, and hundreds of miles from anywhere else I'd ever been lies one of the darkest places in the country, tucked away from the bleeding glow of civilization.

item.title: Did A Violin Teacher From Plano, Texas Solve The World's Greatest Classical Music Mystery? (2017)
item.description: Far from the ivory towers of music academia, Bob Padgett has emerged as perhaps the most prolific and dogged of all Enigma seekers.

item.title: Indy Vice (2017)
item.description: When Randy Lanier sped to Rookie of the Year honors at the 1986 Indianapolis 500, few knew his racing credentials, let alone his status as one of the nation's most prolific drug runners, smuggling in tons of marijuana when he wasn't on the track.

item.title: The Concussion Diaries: One High School Football Player's Secret Struggle with CTE
item.description: Zac Easter knew what was happening to him. He knew why. And he knew that it was only going to get worse. So he decided to write it all down — to let the world know what football had done to him, what he'd done to his body and his brain for the game he loved. And then he shot himself.

item.title: The Obsessed, Feuding Searchers Still Looking For Amelia Earhart (2016)
item.description: Seventy-nine-year-old mysteries don't really get solved. They just linger, the perfect breeding ground for even more theories — and, in this case, a lot of animosity.

item.title: A Terrifying Journey Through The World's Most Dangerous Jungle (2016)
item.description: The Darién Gap is a lawless wilderness on the border of Colombia and Panama, teeming with everything from deadly snakes to antigovernment guerrillas.

item.title: A Junket To The Most 'Interesting' Town On Earth (2016)
item.description: How a trip to the Australian outback got weird, and beautiful.

item.title: My Wet And Wild Bitcoin Weekend On Richard Branson's Island Refuge (2016)
item.description: How the global economy is being overturned by men in flip flops.

item.title: This Drug-Fueled, Multimillion-Dollar Supermodel Snowpocalypse Has Been Fashion's Best-Kept Secret Since 1977 (2016)
item.description: The epic, never-before-told story behind possibly the greatest fashion emergency in history and a daring, near-deadly escape​.

item.title: The Great Bitcoin Experiment That Failed (2016)
item.description: St. Petersburg was supposed to be the "Bitcoin capital of the world." It isn't.

item.title: What I Learned from Losing $200 Million
item.description: The 2008 financial crisis taught me about the illusion of control, and how to give it up.

item.title: If You Give A Hunk A Cookie (2015)
item.description: A day in the life of model, health coach, social media star, and ketogenic cookie guru Crosby Tailor

item.title: Her Family Owned The Building. The Nazis Took It Away. Now She Wanted Justice (2015)
item.description: "I've come to claim my family's building," I told him. Herr Münch looked nonplussed, perhaps even slightly amused.

item.title: DARE: The Anti-Drug Program That Never Actually Worked (2015)
item.description: Studies showed early on that kids who went through DARE weren't any less likely to do drugs. Why did schools keep using it?
item.kicker: ALL WE GOT IS THIS T-SHIRT

item.title: A Tumor Stole Every Memory I Had. This Is What Happened When It All Came Back (2015)
item.description: My brain tumor introduced itself to me on a grainy MRI, in the summer of 2009, when I was 28 years old.

item.title: The WWII-Era Plane Giving The F-35 A Run For Its Money (2015)
item.description: The war in Afghanistan proved that we can't just rely on new technology, but the Pentagon wouldn't listen — and troops paid the price.

item.title: Why Is Light So Fast? (2015)
item.description: Light travels at around 300,000 km per second. Why not faster? Why not slower? A new theory inches us closer to an answer.

item.title: The Abandoned Plan That Could Have Saved America From Drought (2015)
item.description: The North American Water and Power Alliance was an audacious proposal to divert water to parched western states that would have cost hundreds of billions of dollars and pissed off Canada. But what if it had worked?

item.title: The Murder House (2015)
item.description: A mysterious mansion. A murder-suicide. Paranormal activity. This is the true story of 2475 Glendower Place.

item.title: How The Body's Trillions Of Clocks Keep Time (2015)
item.description: Cellular clocks are almost everywhere. Clues to how they work are coming from the places that they're not.

item.title: Slender Man Is Watching (2015)
item.description: If 12-year-olds Anissa Weier and Morgan Geyser knew that the internet character they worshipped was a fantasy, why did they want to kill their friend for him?

item.title: The Talented Mr. Khater (2015)
item.description: When 23-year-old Callie Quinn moved from Texas to Chile, she counted on finding a beautiful country, meaningful work, and interesting friends. She had no idea she'd set off a manhunt for an international con artist.

item.title: The Blind Man Who Taught Himself To See (2012)
item.description: Daniel Kish has been sightless since he was a year old. Yet he can mountain bike. And navigate the wilderness alone. And recognize a building as far away as 1,000 feet. How? The same way bats can see in the dark.

item.title: The Mysterious Murder Of A Nun Who Knew Too Much (2015)
item.description: Baltimore parents trusted Father Joseph Maskell. Maybe they shouldn't have.

item.title: Hostage Camp (2015)
item.description: Inside the strange world of kidnap and ransom survival schools.

item.title: Elon Musk's Space Dream Almost Killed Tesla
item.description: SpaceX started with a plan to send mice to Mars. It got crazier from there.

item.title: The Rise And Fall Of Bill Pettis, The Man With The Biggest Arms In The World (2015)
item.description: His biceps once trumped Arnold's. As other Gold's Gym icons parlayed their physiques into fame and fortune, Bill Pettis took a different route — one that landed him on the Venice Boardwalk.

item.title: The Wedding Sting (2015)
item.description: How a police department tried to save a failing Rust Belt town by luring all the local drug dealers to one party.

item.title: 'We're Probably A Little Sick (2015)
item.description: Most of us enjoy a small wager when we play. But for some golfers it doesn't start to get interesting until big, big, BIG MONEY is at stake.

item.title: Living With Being Dead (2015)
item.description: This terrifying disorder turns people into zombies, into living, breathing ghosts; they believe they died, or never existed. And somewhere in their brains may be the key to human consciousness.

item.title: The Pollen Detective
item.description: Dallas Mildenhall used obscure science to crack cases all over the world. Then a murder took place in his own backyard.
